ps140: 1, Podoben “The joy of the heavenly ranks…”
Let Pamphilus and Seleucius,* together with Valens and Paul,* Porphyrius, Theodulus and Julian,* and the company of the five Egyptians* be melodiously hymned with faith* as a harp of twelve strings.

Exalted splendidly in the Faith of Christ* by divine glory, O glorious Pamphilus,* you were shown to be the goodly adornment of Caesarea,* being therein an all-beloved hierarch, in accordance with your name,* a most honoured athlete* and a faithful martyr.

O mighty Pamphilus,* you assembled a company of valiant athletes, twelve in number,* who showed themselves to be a godly army.* And vanquishing the enemy together,* you were taken to the Lord in diverse ways,* reposing amid your martyrdom.
theotokion: With the staff of your intercession,* O pure Theotokos,* drive from my wretched soul the bestial passions,* guiding me peacefully toward life;* and add me to the holy flock* of your chosen sheep.
stavrotheotokion: When the immaculate Virgin beheld her Lamb uplifted upon the Cross,* she cried out, lamenting:* “O my sweet child,* what is this new and all-glorious sight?* How is it that You who hold all things in Your palm* are nailed to the tree in the flesh.”
